definition: to fill/to satisfy/to fulfill/to act in place of/substitute/sufficient/full

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)

sentences.english: Intimidate book sellers by confiscating books deemed unfavourable to the Barisan government.
sentences.chinese: 充公被视为对国阵不利的书籍，威胁书商。

sentences.english: We have a right to your remittance confiscated .
sentences.chinese: 我们有权利把你的汇款充公。

sentences.english: Make maximum use of available legislation to confiscate the proceeds of drug trafficking.
sentences.chinese: 善用现行法律以充公贩毒得益。

sentences.english: In China they may shoot the owner and confiscate the company.
sentences.chinese: 而在中国你会被枪毙，公司会被充公。

sentences.english: The state confiscated land from those who opposed the revolution.
sentences.chinese: 国家将那些反对革命的人的土地充公。

definition: to commandeer/to take over for the state
to search a house and confiscate possessions
to transfer (income, profits etc) to higher authorities
to take inventory of and confiscate a criminal's possessions/to search and confiscate (forbidden items)/to raid
movable property/money and belongings/non-real estate assets
to sell illicitly/to bootleg/to sell privately
to sack/to remove from a position/to depose
to banish (to an army post, as a punishment)
to hand over to/to give to higher authority/to seek connections in high places
